The first is the ability to check in to actual places, like restaurants and stores. "I'm in J. Crew" is.)

docs.snippet: Android users who upgrade to Google Maps 5.1, available since Tuesday, will find a bunch of new features added to Latitude, Google's location-based social network. The first is the ability to check in to actual places, like restaurants and stores....
docs.lead_paragraph: Android users who upgrade to Google Maps 5.1, available since Tuesday, will find a bunch of new features added to Latitude, Google's location-based social network. The first is the ability to check in to actual places, like restaurants and stores. In the past, Latitude users could indicate where they were on a map, but the actual business or building they were in remained a mystery. (''I'm in Rockefeller Center'' is not terribly helpful. ''I'm in J. Crew'' is.) Since Latitude works with Google Maps and Android, it is constantly aware of your location (if you want it to be). That leads to the other enhancements: notification and automatic check-in and checkout. When you arrive somewhere, Latitude can prompt you to check in, in case you have forgotten to do so already. You can also set Latitude up to automatically check yourself in to frequently visited places, like your office. Latitude will also automatically check you out when you leave a location.

headline.main: Google's Latitude Introduces Several New Features

docs.abstract: Gadgetwise blog; Google introduces new features for Latitude, its location-based social network; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Tips for using the "Pin Tab" feature of the Google Chrome Browser....
docs.lead_paragraph: The "Pin Tab" feature of the Google Chrome browser neatly reduces page tabs down to just the site's icon - which can make it easier to switch between screens full of open sites. To shrink a tab down to its icon, right-click on it and choose Pin Tab. While this makes room for plenty of open tabs, it also hides the number of unread messages that is normally displayed on the full tab of an open Gmail page.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Behind the 'Pin Tab' Feature of Google's Chrome Browser

docs.abstract: Tips for using the "Pin Tab" feature of the Google Chrome Browser.

docs.snippet: Humanity's musical treasures -- Beethoven piano sonatas, Schubert songs, Mozart symphonies and the like -- come to life in performance. But they truly survive as black marks on a page, otherwise known as scores. Now a Web site founded five years a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Humanity's musical treasures -- Beethoven piano sonatas, Schubert songs, Mozart symphonies and the like -- come to life in performance. But they truly survive as black marks on a page, otherwise known as scores. Now a Web site founded five years ago by a conservatory student, then 19 years old, has made a vast expanse of this repertory available, free. The site, the Internet Music Score Library Project, has trod in the footsteps of Google Books and Project Gutenberg and grown to be one of the largest sources of scores anywhere. It claims to have 85,000 scores, or parts for nearly 35,000 works, with several thousand being added every month. That is a worrisome pace for traditional music publishers, whose bread and butter comes from renting and selling scores in expensive editions backed by the latest scholarship. More than a business threat, the site has raised messy copyright issues and drawn the ire of established publishers.

headline.main: Free Trove of Music Scores on Web Hits Sensitive Copyright Note

docs.abstract: Internet Music Score Library Project allows free downloads of musical treasures and is raising copyright concerns among traditional music publishers; it claims to have 85,000 scores or parts for nearly 35,000 works with several thousand being added each month; project has turned classical music into latest wrestling mat for conventional information purveyors and new digital forces; photo (M)

docs.snippet: The Motorola Xoom, one of the most eagerly awaited iPad rivals, has arrived. It has slightly upgraded hardware, but its Google tablet software, known as Honeycomb, is the more important story....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Motorola Xoom, one of the most eagerly awaited iPad rivals, has arrived. It has slightly upgraded hardware, but its Google tablet software, known as Honeycomb, is the more important story.

headline.main: Before Rush, One Tablet Stands Out
headline.print_headline: Before Rush, One Tablet Stands Out

docs.snippet: It's an old pattern by now. Phase 1: Apple introduces some new gadget. The bloggers and the industry tell us why it'll fail. Phase 2: It goes on sale. The public goes nuts for it. Phase 3: Every company and its brother gets to work on a copycat.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: It's an old pattern by now. Phase 1: Apple introduces some new gadget. The bloggers and the industry tell us why it'll fail. Phase 2: It goes on sale. The public goes nuts for it. Phase 3: Every company and its brother gets to work on a copycat. It happened with the iMac and the iPhone. Now the iPad is entering Phase 3. Apple sold 15 million iPads in nine months, so you can bet that 2011 will be the Year of the iPad Clone.

headline.main: Before Rush, One Tablet Stands Out

docs.abstract: David Pogue State of The Art column on Motorola Xoom tablet computer; says eagerly awaited iPad rival stands out not because of its updated hardware, but because of Google's Honeycomb version of Android, specifically designed for tablets instead of phones; drawing; photo (M)
